description: From Old English hnol. Cognate with Dutch nol (“top of a sand-dune”).

entries.meaning: (now UK regional) The head, especially the top of the head. [from 8th c.]
examples: Wolde to God it wolde please you some daye / A balade boke before me for to laye, / And lerne me to synge Re my fa sol! / And whan I fayle bobbe me on the noll.
